body:
> Hm, inkscape has grid and alignment tools too, doesn't it? (I don't use inkscape, but I found this and this online.)

They exist but they're way harder to use. And you just can't get the curves as nice or align objects as easily.

> Unfortunately, I don't.

You seem to. I didn't even know you could run JS in the console until today. I still don't know how to track down js calls that aren't defined in the html. I know very little about web requests and APIs and such. You usually do know the things that aren't really documented (such as this and reddit's API). Even if you merely dabble in something, you know at least 2x as much as I do.

> My "learning method" probably isn't that great. I just look up things as I go. When I get interested in/confused about something, I look it up online and usually just look at the first few results.

Most of the stuff you told me I can't find anywhere online (ex. everything about the developer tools and a lot of other computer stuff that you know and I don't).

I'm a very young adult, do you think maybe I'm just not as developed yet (assuming you're older than that)?
body_html:
Hm, inkscape has grid and alignment tools too, doesn't it? (I don't use inkscape, but I found this and this online.)

They exist but they're way harder to use. And you just can't get the curves as nice or align objects as easily.

Unfortunately, I don't.

You seem to. I didn't even know you could run JS in the console until today. I still don't know how to track down js calls that aren't defined in the html. I know very little about web requests and APIs and such. You usually do know the things that aren't really documented (such as this and reddit's API). Even if you merely dabble in something, you know at least 2x as much as I do.

My "learning method" probably isn't that great. I just look up things as I go. When I get interested in/confused about something, I look it up online and usually just look at the first few results.

Most of the stuff you told me I can't find anywhere online (ex. everything about the developer tools and a lot of other computer stuff that you know and I don't).

I'm a very young adult, do you think maybe I'm just not as developed yet (assuming you're older than that)?

guild.description:
A uuid is unique, it is one of a kind, it is ephemeral. A uuid is generated for a purpose and then tossed aside, never to be seen or used again.

Generate and post a uuid to give it a meaning a little longer than most. Each post should serve to honor the beauty of a single uuid. Maybe your uuid has certain properties that make it special. Maybe there is a sequence or palindrome in a substring of that uuid.

Let's talk about them.

Let's talk about them.
guild.name: uuid

parent.body:
Hm, inkscape has grid and alignment tools too, doesn't it? (I don't use inkscape, but I found [this](https://inkscape-manuals.readthedocs.io/en/latest/align-and-distribute.html) and [this](https://graphicdesign.stackexchange.com/questions/63403/snap-to-grid-in-inkscape) online.)

>ex. the wine in the wine glass

I don't really remember what I did, but I think it was this. First, I drew the shape of the cup. Then, I set the fill color to maroon and the outline (stroke) color to white. Then, I drew a triangle at the bottom where the base aligns with the top of the liquid, I converted it to freeform, and I tried to get it to be as close as possible to the shape I want.

>you know every little bell and whistle they have, and exactly how requests, js, python, sessions, cookies, etc. work

Unfortunately, I don't.

>Do you have a deliberate learning method of some kind?

My "learning method" probably isn't that great. I just look up things as I go. When I get interested in/confused about something, I look it up online and usually just look at the first few results.

body:
Actually, I just figured out the whole vector thing! The powerpoint programs have a grid and other alignment tools that makes it easier to draw "perfect" unlike inkscape where is geared more towards freehand.

However, I still have questions. There are situations where you had to have drawn off-grid (ex. the wine in the wine glass, that shape can't align properly on a grid). So how are you managing it in those cases?

Also I still wonder how you learn things so thoroughly (the dev tools in browsers are one example, you know every little bell and whistle they have, and exactly how requests, js, python, sessions, cookies, etc. work, even when I don't because I can't find any answers online; and you're not even a programmer). You seem to just automatically know everything about everything. Do you have a deliberate learning method of some kind?
body_html:

parent.body:
I wanted to clear a few things up.

1. My submission wasn't meant to be a joke submission. I was asking if joke submissions were okay since I saw others making them (the purple snoo and the one by milkit).
2. I've been drawing for over 8 years, which means I do have some experience/practice. (I've never taken classes on digital art though, and I don't know that much about perspective/shading since I just draw for fun). I just don't really post any of my drawings online. (You definitely have a lot more experience in programming though.)
3. Like Seq37 said, my drawing isn't exactly perfect. There's some misalignment at the bottom, and I also wasn't sure how to get it to be symmetric (I drew the left side first, and I copied and pasted it to make the right side, but I had trouble connecting the two sides together), so it ended up having some asymmetry.
4. I don't really just "skim over" the code and see bugs every time. Like Seq37 said, I think I also try to look at individual lines and try to think of ways to "abuse" them. I usually try to think of things like unconventional inputs or cases that the devs may have forgotten about.
5. (Also, the least important thing: I'm actually a girl, but that probably doesn't matter)

>very clever manner

What do you mean?

>he quickly imagined a creature with distinct features, and ones that fit and make a lot of sense too, not just random

The tentacles and arms were completely random. The ears were kind of based on elf ears, but that's it. I'm sort of wondering what you thought the features meant (if you can find meaning from them, that would be pretty cool).

What I did here was that I tried to think of the general shape of the creature (is it humanoid, is it a blob, is it an object, is it something else?), and I tried to think of what it should have on each part of the body (What should it have on the head? Should it have arms or wings or anything like that? Are there any features that would make it feel medieval?) However, if you'd like advice on coming up with ideas, I'm probably not the best person to ask since I usually have trouble with it (I tried to think of a flag for ruqqus a while back and still haven't come up with anything).

I actually think your depiction is pretty good (in my opinion, at least). I think that some changes I would make is that I'd make the mouth and the bottom of the crown a bit rounder (I drew the crown on mine using triangles and an oval), and I'd make the arms a bit less thin. I also think that the shading on the left is a bit awkward (it makes the arm seem flat, and the bottom is not connected to the edge of the body), but since I'm not that knowledgeable about shading, I don't really know how to fix it. (If I were to do it, I'd probably end up making the entire left side of the body darker, assuming the light is coming from the top right.)

>Acikek is similar to sfrohne and is also much younger than I am, yet also does everything consistently and solidly

I usually feel this way too when seeing someone who's younger and lot more talented than I am. But then I realize that their abilities probably came from a lot of practice and a lot of time spent on learning about the thing they're good at.

I don't think that it's too good to self-deprecate like this. I think that if you want to improve on drawing, for example, you can try showing one of your drawings to someone who's better at it and ask for advice. You can also try looking up resources on specific things like shading/perspective.

For memes and shitposting about everything that happens in our beloved "Official Ruqqus Discord"
 
---

## Posting Rules


Rule 1: 

This guild is for shitposting about people/events in the Ruqqus Discord server. Any post that is not related to this will be kicked to +general. If you need help regarding the discord server, +askruqqus, +general, or +hub would gladly accept your questions.


Rule 2:

No spamming. Spamming would be considered any of the following:

* Same-format posting within a day

* Same-content posting within a day (Same content, different format)


Spammed posts will get kicked and repeated offenses results in being exiled.


Rule 3: 

No reposts: reposts are cringe. Any reposts will be kicked.

guild.description:
This guild is about News far and wide!

Sister guild: +Commentary

#1. Things that are posted to News should be stated like a fact in the Headline.

In the sense, Headline: X happened or X said this. Not Personal opinions. 

They should be reporting.

#2. Personal slant or commentary should go in the comments, not the Headline. Commentary content (like discussion commentator shows) are not News. Commentary content will be redirected to +Commentary which is for that purpose. 

If it's News but is more an opinion piece please add [Opinion] in the title, or post in a topic specific guild. 

#3. No screenshots; provide a link, provide a source.

See Posting Etiquette pin for further explanation.

body:
Okay, here's an image highlighting all my vector image issues that you don't have:

![](https://i.imgur.com/acyUysX.png)

You probably need to zoom in to see some of them.

You're way better at programming than me (reading and testing it at least, but you'd crush me if you started writing too) and pretty much everything else we both do too. You just seem like a savant who has a 150+ IQ in addition to a fair amount of creativity. I'm more like a 120 IQ (most studies find that to be an inherited trait, mine is one of the lowest I've seen from our types, yours is one of the highest) and have zero creativity (seems to be harder for men for some reason, all the others I know with our personality are male and none of them have it either, and I doubt the stereotype of girls being more creative most of the time is an accident). And I am very slow and have trouble doing things consistently and properly, everything turns out to be a mess, and I can't find or learn things very fast either (probably executive functioning issues, which I also pretty much just have to live with). And even a lot of the stuff I can do and know is just me mimicking the actually smart people. All those traits appear to be fixed at birth, which is why I get so angry sometimes because I know I can't really do anything about any of them. I feel an inclination towards the same things you do but my ability and brainpower to do them is nerfed. But fortunately talking to you and some of the others over the past week I feel has helped me a little bit, so I think there may be a glimmer of hope for me to at least improve with some of these things.

guild.description:
A uuid is unique, it is one of a kind, it is ephemeral. A uuid is generated for a purpose and then tossed aside, never to be seen or used again.

Generate and post a uuid to give it a meaning a little longer than most. Each post should serve to honor the beauty of a single uuid. Maybe your uuid has certain properties that make it special. Maybe there is a sequence or palindrome in a substring of that uuid.

Let's talk about them.

parent.body:
I wanted to clear a few things up.

1. My submission wasn't meant to be a joke submission. I was asking if joke submissions were okay since I saw others making them (the purple snoo and the one by milkit).
2. I've been drawing for over 8 years, which means I do have some experience/practice. (I've never taken classes on digital art though, and I don't know that much about perspective/shading since I just draw for fun). I just don't really post any of my drawings online. (You definitely have a lot more experience in programming though.)
3. Like Seq37 said, my drawing isn't exactly perfect. There's some misalignment at the bottom, and I also wasn't sure how to get it to be symmetric (I drew the left side first, and I copied and pasted it to make the right side, but I had trouble connecting the two sides together), so it ended up having some asymmetry.
4. I don't really just "skim over" the code and see bugs every time. Like Seq37 said, I think I also try to look at individual lines and try to think of ways to "abuse" them. I usually try to think of things like unconventional inputs or cases that the devs may have forgotten about.
5. (Also, the least important thing: I'm actually a girl, but that probably doesn't matter)

>very clever manner

What do you mean?

>he quickly imagined a creature with distinct features, and ones that fit and make a lot of sense too, not just random

The tentacles and arms were completely random. The ears were kind of based on elf ears, but that's it. I'm sort of wondering what you thought the features meant (if you can find meaning from them, that would be pretty cool).

What I did here was that I tried to think of the general shape of the creature (is it humanoid, is it a blob, is it an object, is it something else?), and I tried to think of what it should have on each part of the body (What should it have on the head? Should it have arms or wings or anything like that? Are there any features that would make it feel medieval?) However, if you'd like advice on coming up with ideas, I'm probably not the best person to ask since I usually have trouble with it (I tried to think of a flag for ruqqus a while back and still haven't come up with anything).

I actually think your depiction is pretty good (in my opinion, at least). I think that some changes I would make is that I'd make the mouth and the bottom of the crown a bit rounder (I drew the crown on mine using triangles and an oval), and I'd make the arms a bit less thin. I also think that the shading on the left is a bit awkward (it makes the arm seem flat, and the bottom is not connected to the edge of the body), but since I'm not that knowledgeable about shading, I don't really know how to fix it. (If I were to do it, I'd probably end up making the entire left side of the body darker, assuming the light is coming from the top right.)

>Acikek is similar to sfrohne and is also much younger than I am, yet also does everything consistently and solidly

I usually feel this way too when seeing someone who's younger and lot more talented than I am. But then I realize that their abilities probably came from a lot of practice and a lot of time spent on learning about the thing they're good at.

I don't think that it's too good to self-deprecate like this. I think that if you want to improve on drawing, for example, you can try showing one of your drawings to someone who's better at it and ask for advice. You can also try looking up resources on specific things like shading/perspective.

parent.body: I looked at what clicking the "tip" button did, and apparently it calls [this](https://github.com/ruqqus/ruqqus/blob/d22b846d8f53d8c67c5ed40c6ae228cff2fc3331/ruqqus/assets/js/all_js.js#L1891). So I copied the `post_toast('/gift_'+ content +'/' + id + '?coins=1', callback = function() {location.href = link})` part and filled in the values (which included replacing the 1 with -999), and I copied and pasted it into the console. (I had no idea what I was doing, so I also deleted the callback for some reason, but yeah)

post.body:
I'm not intelligent enough for this site. I was born to be an average sheep who would still be using reddit and watching CNN right now.

I'm only smart because I've thought too much. I became fed up with the establishment early in life and began questioning things. Otherwise I'd have never noticed anything. I also have many interests (and I suck at doing all of them). There's a difference between smart and genius. Smart is what you work for and accumulate over years of work, study, research, and practice. Anyone can become smart, and I'm very smart in many areas. However, I'm definitely not a genius. Genius is what you're born with, talent and intelligence. Geniuses have an instinct or intuition that allows them to start out 10x better at something without trying than the most hard-working non-genius will ever get to. Genius is a whole new level, and it's not available for everyone. Geniuses are naturally smart, and unfortunately as a smart person, especially in an open-source community full of these people, almost everyone I know is a genius. I can't do anything they can do. I'm a tryhard, a wannabe or whatever. My existence here, at least in the early stages of this site, is pointless. I simply didn't inherit the right genes for this type of thing, or most things I want to do. I just wasn't born for it.

Most people here can do anything if they try even a little bit. Most active posters, even brand new ones, easily find 100s of great things in an hour, and super creative titles to go along with some of them. I on the other hand, despite 3 years of experience, can't manage to find more than one or two mediocre things in 2 hours that I haven't seen before. Most active commenters somehow find every single major post in the first 60 seconds and always get the top comments. Most devs here are true programmers, while I'm just a guy who copies and pastes things together and hopes it works. Even non-programmers completely blow me out of the water most of the time. And I've been at this for many years.

My problem is, I know a lot, but I'm dull. I'm the type who can pretend to be gifted, get good grades, etc. But when it really comes down to it, I'm nothing special. For example, you all are the people who can legitimately figure out a complicated math or science problem, whereas I can never do that. I have to be taught literally every step of everything, then I can copy it well enough, but never do it on my own. This is *crucial* for anything I want to accomplish myself; anytime I need to do something that's not been done before, I simply can't. I can't figure anything out. I can only copy others' methods. Yet you all have that genius instinct, to know how to do all these amazing things. I can't do that. I don't belong with you. You are all innovators. I am not, am uncreative, can't think outside the box, a talentless hack, etc. You are the people who make a difference. As for me, my only option is the usual college, job I hate, retire, then die, having nothing to do with my life. Try as I might, no amount of practice or desire will get me the talent I need to accomplish anything for real.

No, I'm not going to delete my account. But I'm not going to try and contribute as much anymore. It's pointless, a waste of time for me to try. You've all got it covered already. I'll just be around as a less active, more normal user.
